questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for pain and swelling in the right elbow 45 minutes after he fell while playing on the monkey bars during recess. He has been unable to move his right elbow since the fall. Examination shows ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the humeral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with open fractures are vulnerable to polymicrobial infection. Wound management for open fractures routinely involves irrigation and prophylactic antibiotics. Although this patient's fracture is displaced, it is closed. Therefore, he is unlikely to sustain a polymicrobial infection.

B) CORRECT:

Distal humerus fractures, including supracondylar fractures, can lead to brachial artery injury either by entrapping or directly injuring the artery. Even if the brachial artery is not directly affected, local trauma can also induce brachial artery vasospasm, thus compromising arterial blood flow. Impaired brachial artery flow affects the distal structures supplied by this artery, so patients can have an absent or diminished radial pulse and delayed capillary refill in the affected arm. Most patients do not have a direct injury of the artery and treatment of the fracture (internal fixation) usually reduces entrapment and restores perfusion; vascular surgery is rarely needed.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired arm abduction can occur following axillary nerve injuries, which are associated with proximal humerus fracture. In contrast, this patient has a distal humerus fracture. Distal fractures can be associated with radial, ulnar, and/or median nerve injuries, but the axillary nerve is usually not injured in distal fractures (see “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table). Nerve injuries in patients with distal humerus fractures are typically neurapraxias and most patients recover fully within 3 months.

D) INCORRECT:

The humeral head is supplied by the axillary artery through the circumflex humeral arteries. Injury to these arteries most commonly occurs in patients with proximal humerus fractures (especially at the level of the surgical neck) and can lead to avascular necrosis. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to injure the axillary artery.

E) INCORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (i.e., frozen shoulder) is characterized by pain, stiffness, and decreased range of motion in the shoulder joint and can occur following humeral fractures. However, adhesive capsulitis typically results from postoperative shoulder immobility or from fractures to the proximal humerus. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to cause frozen shoulder.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows a displaced supracondylar humerus fracture, the most common elbow fracture in children.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department because of right elbow swelling and pain 30 minutes after falling onto her outstretched right arm. She has been unable to move her right elbow since the fall. Physical examination shows bruising, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm shows a supracondylar fracture of the humerus with anterior displacement of the proximal fragment. Further evaluation is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Because the distal segment of the brachial artery lies on the anterior surface of the distal humerus, the brachial artery is commonly injured with distal humerus fractures (e.g., supracondylar fractures). Such a fracture can injure the brachial artery directly or indirectly (local trauma can induce brachial artery vasospasm even if the brachial artery is not directly affected) and compromise arterial blood flow distal to the brachial artery. The brachial artery bifurcates into the radial artery and ulnar artery within the cubital fossa. A weak or absent radial pulse with a humerus fracture indicates disruption of the supplying brachial artery.

Displaced supracondylar fractures may also injure the radial nerve and median nerve, which lie close to the distal humerus. Ulnar nerve injury is rare with supracondylar fractures and typically occurs with medial epicondylar fractures.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

B) INCORRECT:

Damage to the ulnar nerve causes radial deviation of the wrist (proximal lesions), finger spreading, and flexion of the last two digits. Ulnar nerve damage due to supracondylar fractures is possible but very rare and only occurs with flexion-type supracondylar fractures (i.e., posterior displacement of the proximal fragment). A different examination finding is more likely with this patient's fracture pattern.

C) INCORRECT:

The inability to abduct the shoulder suggests damage to the axillary nerve, which innervates the deltoid muscle. However, the axillary nerve branches off from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and is too proximal to be damaged by a supracondylar fracture.

D) INCORRECT:

The brachial artery is a continuation of the axillary artery, passing below the level of teres major. Impairments of blood flow from the axillary artery, therefore, manifest with pulselessness at the proximal brachial artery. However, the proximal brachial artery will be spared by a distal humerus fracture (e.g., supracondylar fracture).

E) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the primary elbow flexors, i.e., biceps, brachialis, and coracobrachialis muscles. Musculocutaneous nerve injury is rare and associated with axillary injuries, proximal humerus fractures, and humeral shaft fractures but not distal humerus fractures (e.g., supracondylar fractures). Injury to the sensory branch of the musculocutaneous nerve (e.g., the lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve) is possible with a distal humerus fracture but manifests with anterior lateral elbow and forearm paresthesias rather than muscle weakness. The brachioradialis muscle is another elbow flexor but this muscle is innervated by the radial nerve near the middle segment of the humerus and is unlikely to be affected by a distal humerus fracture.
questions.hint: In supracondylar fractures, the proximal fragment of the distally fractured humerus can displace anteriorly into soft tissue structures, impinging important blood vessels and nerves.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents for evaluation of left shoulder pain and swelling. She tripped on a curb today while walking out of the grocery store and fell on her outstretched arm. She was initially unable to move the arm at the shoulder and has had continuous pain with any attempted movement of the upper arm. The pain improves when she holds her arm very still in a resting position at her side.
Her upper arm is bruised and swollen 3 to 5 cm distal to the glenohumeral joint. She is able to actively abduct the arm to 30 degrees, but this movement is accompanied by significant pain. She has full range of motion at the elbow and wrist. Her upper arm is tender to palpation below the acromion. There is no tenderness over the elbow, forearm, wrist, or hand. Her neurovascular examination, including sensation over the medial deltoid, is normal.
What is the most likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Although there are no specific examination tests for the diagnosis of proximal humerus fractures, findings of pain with shoulder movement and focal tenderness at the proximal humerus after a fall should raise suspicion for a proximal humerus fracture. Proximal humerus fractures are common fractures in older adults and usually occur as the result of a low-energy fall. They are often minimally displaced and can be managed nonoperatively. Surgical intervention is typically reserved for patients who have more-complex fractures (such as an open fracture, compound fracture with >50 degrees of displacement, or an associated vascular injury) and those who require complete shoulder function.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in a patient with shoulder pain that is exacerbated by shoulder movement and characterized by tenderness just below the acromion is fracture of the proximal humerus.

B) INCORRECT:

A distal radius fracture can occur after a fall onto an outstretched hand but would be characterized by tenderness and/or diminished range of motion at the wrist and distal forearm.

C) INCORRECT:

A deltoid nerve injury is unlikely in a patient who has normal sensation over the medial deltoid; in addition, it is inconsistent with the mechanism of this patient's injury.

D) INCORRECT:

A distal biceps tendon tear can occur after trauma but is typically associated with medial elbow pain on elbow flexion and supination.

E) INCORRECT:

Parsonage-Turner syndrome is an acute brachial neuritis that is associated with severe pain and weakness in the shoulder and upper extremity. It is uncommon, and it is not associated with trauma. Furthermore, one would not expect point tenderness over the proximal humerus.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for pain and swelling in the right elbow 45 minutes after he fell while playing on the monkey bars during recess. He has been unable to move his right elbow since the fall. Examination shows ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow; range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm is shown. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the humeral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with open fractures are vulnerable to polymicrobial infection. Wound management for open fractures routinely involves irrigation and prophylactic antibiotics. Although this patient's fracture is displaced, it is closed. Therefore, he is unlikely to sustain a polymicrobial infection.

B) CORRECT:

Distal humerus fractures, including supracondylar fractures, can lead to brachial artery injury either by entrapping or directly injuring the artery. Even if the brachial artery is not directly affected, local trauma can also induce brachial artery vasospasm, thus compromising arterial blood flow. Impaired brachial artery flow affects the distal structures supplied by this artery, so patients can have an absent or diminished radial pulse and delayed capillary refill in the affected arm. Most patients do not have a direct injury of the artery and treatment of the fracture (internal fixation) usually reduces entrapment and restores perfusion; vascular surgery is rarely needed.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

Impaired arm abduction can occur following axillary nerve injuries, which are associated with proximal humerus fracture. In contrast, this patient has a distal humerus fracture. Distal fractures can be associated with radial, ulnar, and/or median nerve injuries, but the axillary nerve is usually not injured in distal fractures (see “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table). Nerve injuries in patients with distal humerus fractures are typically neurapraxias and most patients recover fully within 3 months.

D) INCORRECT:

The humeral head is supplied by the axillary artery through the circumflex humeral arteries. Injury to these arteries most commonly occurs in patients with proximal humerus fractures (especially at the level of the surgical neck) and can lead to avascular necrosis. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to injure the axillary artery.

E) INCORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (i.e., frozen shoulder) is characterized by pain, stiffness, and decreased range of motion in the shoulder joint and can occur following humeral fractures. However, adhesive capsulitis typically results from postoperative shoulder immobility or from fractures to the proximal humerus. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to cause frozen shoulder.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows a displaced supracondylar humerus fracture, the most common elbow fracture in children.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the Emergency Department after falling from a monkey bar. He has significant elbow swelling, severe pain, and an obvious deformity around the distal humerus. Physical examination reveals limited range of motion due to pain, absent radial and ulnar pulses in the affected arm, and a cool hand to the touch. Sensation is intact.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Obtain vascular imaging and monitor pulses
Immobilize in a long arm cast
Elevate the arm and reassess pulses in 2 hours

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vascular imaging is useful when vascular injury diagnosis is uncertain. However, in this case, the absence of radial and ulnar pulses and a cool hand strongly indicate acute arterial injury. Delaying intervention for imaging could extend ischemia duration and increase limb loss risk. Immediate intervention is necessary to restore perfusion.

B) INCORRECT:

Immobilization in a long arm cast is appropriate for fractures without neurovascular compromise. In this case, absent pulses and a cool hand suggest vascular injury, likely brachial artery entrapment. Casting would not resolve vascular compromise, risking further ischemic injury. Immediate reduction and vascular assessment are required.

C) INCORRECT:

Elevation can reduce edema in less severe injuries, but absent pulses and a cool hand indicate significant vascular compromise. Waiting risks prolonged ischemia and complications like compartment syndrome. Immediate evaluation and intervention are needed for mechanical vascular disruption due to a displaced fracture.

D) CORRECT:

In a pediatric patient with a supracondylar humerus fracture, absent radial and ulnar pulses, and a cool hand, there is a high suspicion of brachial artery injury causing acute limb ischemia. Immediate open surgical exploration is necessary to directly visualize and repair the injured vessel and reduce the fracture. This intervention restores distal perfusion and minimizes the risk of ischemic complications, such as compartment syndrome or permanent neurologic deficits. Timely surgical intervention is critical in managing fractures with associated vascular injuries to preserve limb function.

Key learning point: In the case of a supracondylar fracture with absent distal pulses, immediate surgical exploration is necessary to assess and address potential vascular injury to prevent ischemia and permanent limb damage.

questions.text:
A 27-year-old man is brought to the Emergency Department after falling from a height. He complains of severe pain in his right arm. Examination reveals a displaced fracture over the middle third of the humerus. He cannot extend his wrist or fingers and reports numbness over the dorsum of his hand (see report).
Radiographs: Mid-shaft humeral fracture with displacement
Which of the following nerves is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ulnar nerve supplies the intrinsic muscles of the hand and certain forearm flexors, with sensory distribution to the medial hand, particularly the little finger and adjacent half of the ring finger. Ulnar nerve injuries are more common with trauma around the elbow, not midshaft humeral fractures. The motor and sensory deficits described do not align with ulnar nerve distribution.

B) CORRECT:

The radial nerve runs along the spiral groove of the humerus, making it vulnerable to injury in midshaft humeral fractures. This nerve provides motor innervation to the extensor muscles of the forearm, and its injury results in wrist drop due to loss of wrist and finger extension. Additionally, the radial nerve supplies sensation to the dorsal aspect of the hand, particularly the radial side, explaining the patient's numbness in that area. The combination of these motor and sensory deficits is characteristic of radial nerve injury in the context of a midshaft humeral fracture.

Key learning point: A displaced fracture of the mid shaft of the humerus can lead to radial nerve injury, resulting in wrist drop due to the inability to extend the wrist and fingers.

C) INCORRECT:

The median nerve primarily innervates the flexor muscles of the forearm and provides sensory input to the palmar aspect of the lateral hand and thumb. It does not supply the extensor muscles or the dorsum of the hand. The patient's inability to extend the wrist and fingers and sensory loss over the dorsum of the hand are not consistent with median nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve innervates the anterior compartment of the arm, facilitating elbow flexion, and provides sensation to the lateral forearm. It does not affect wrist or finger extension or sensation on the dorsal hand. The clinical findings of wrist drop and dorsal hand numbness are inconsistent with musculocutaneous nerve injury.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old woman presents to the Emergency Department after falling down a flight of stairs onto her right side, landing on her right shoulder. She has immediate severe shoulder pain. She has a history of osteoporosis. On examination, she holds her right arm adducted and experiences marked pain upon any attempt at active abduction beyond 15 degrees. The humeral head region is tender on palpation. Distal pulses and wrist extension are intact, and sensation in the forearm is normal (see report).
Radiographs of the right shoulder: Fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus with slight displacement
Which additional clinical finding is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Inability to extend at the wrist
Loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder
Loss of sensation over the medial forearm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wrist extension is controlled by the radial nerve, which is not typically affected by a surgical neck fracture of the humerus. The axillary nerve, which is more likely to be injured in this type of fracture, affects shoulder abduction, not wrist extension. The intact wrist extension in this patient further indicates preserved radial nerve function.

B) CORRECT:

A fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus often results in axillary nerve injury. The axillary nerve innervates the deltoid and teres minor muscles, facilitating arm abduction beyond 15 degrees, and provides sensory innervation to the lateral shoulder, known as the 'regimental badge' area. Injury to this nerve can lead to both impaired arm abduction and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder. This aligns with the patient's inability to abduct the arm beyond 15 degrees and tenderness in the humeral head region.

Key learning point: A fracture at the surgical neck of the humerus is most commonly associated with injury to the axillary nerve, which can lead to weakness in shoulder abduction and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder.

C) INCORRECT:

The medial forearm is innervated by the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve, originating from the medial cord of the brachial plexus. This nerve is not typically affected by a surgical neck fracture of the humerus, which is more likely to involve the axillary nerve, affecting the lateral shoulder.

D) INCORRECT:

Elbow flexion is primarily mediated by the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles, innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. This nerve is anatomically distant from the surgical neck of the humerus, where the axillary nerve is more likely to be injured. The clinical presentation suggests axillary nerve involvement, not musculocutaneous nerve injury.

questions.text: You are seeing a 21-year-old woman who is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. She reports significant pain and weakness in her right arm and hand. On examination, there are multiple ecchymoses and tenderness in the right upper extremity. She is able to make a fist, but her grip strength is markedly decreased. An x-ray of the right upper extremity reveals a midshaft humerus fracture. Which one of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a mid-shaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.

C) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.

D) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with mid-shaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. It is typically associated with wrist drop, decreased finger extensor strength, and loss of sensation over the dorsal hand and forearm. Decreased grip strength can also be present due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures the optimal action of finger flexors) but the ability to make a fist is not affected.

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.

Key learning point: Midshaft humerus fractures commonly injure the radial nerve, leading to wrist drop and decreased grip strength due to impaired wrist extension.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

E) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.
questions.hint: This patient most likely cannot extend her hand at the wrist joint.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-year-old boy who is brought to the emergency department with pain and swelling in his right elbow, 45 minutes after falling from monkey bars during recess. He has been unable to move his right elbow since the injury. On examination, there is ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness of the right elbow, and range of motion is limited by pain. An x-ray of the right arm is provided. Which one of the following complications is this patient at greatest risk for?

choices.text: Avascular necrosis of the humeral head.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Adhesive capsulitis (i.e., frozen shoulder) is characterized by pain, stiffness, and decreased range of motion in the shoulder joint and can occur following humeral fractures. However, adhesive capsulitis typically results from postoperative shoulder immobility or from fractures to the proximal humerus. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to cause frozen shoulder.

B) INCORRECT:

Impaired arm abduction can occur following axillary nerve injuries, which are associated with proximal humerus fracture. In contrast, this patient has a distal humerus fracture. Distal fractures can be associated with radial, ulnar, and/or median nerve injuries, but the axillary nerve is usually not injured in distal fractures (see “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table). Nerve injuries in patients with distal humerus fractures are typically neurapraxias and most patients recover fully within 3 months.

C) INCORRECT:

Patients with open fractures are vulnerable to polymicrobial infection. Wound management for open fractures routinely involves irrigation and prophylactic antibiotics. Although this patient's fracture is displaced, it is closed. Therefore, he is unlikely to sustain a polymicrobial infection.

D) INCORRECT:

The humeral head is supplied by the axillary artery through the circumflex humeral arteries. Injury to these arteries most commonly occurs in patients with proximal humerus fractures (especially at the level of the surgical neck) and can lead to avascular necrosis. This patient has a distal humerus fracture, which is unlikely to injure the axillary artery.

E) CORRECT:

Distal humerus fractures, including supracondylar fractures, can lead to brachial artery injury either by entrapping or directly injuring the artery. Even if the brachial artery is not directly affected, local trauma can also induce brachial artery vasospasm, thus compromising arterial blood flow. Impaired brachial artery flow affects the distal structures supplied by this artery, so patients can have an absent or diminished radial pulse and delayed capillary refill in the affected arm. Most patients do not have a direct injury of the artery and treatment of the fracture (internal fixation) usually reduces entrapment and restores perfusion; vascular surgery is rarely needed.

Key learning point: Supracondylar humerus fractures commonly risk brachial artery injury, which can lead to an absent or diminished radial pulse and compromised distal perfusion.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.
questions.hint: The x-ray shows a displaced supracondylar humerus fracture, the most common elbow fracture in children.

questions.text: A 42-year-old carpenter presents after falling from a ladder onto his right side. He reports severe right upper arm pain and inability to use his hand properly. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness over the mid-humerus with an intact radial pulse and normal capillary refill. When asked to make a fist and extend his wrist, he is unable to lift his wrist off the examination table against gravity. There is also weakness with finger extension at the metacarpophalangeal joints. Sensation is diminished over the dorsal aspect of the first web space. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Immobilize in an arm sling and arrange outpatient follow-up
Apply a coaptation splint and consult orthopedics urgently
Apply a long arm posterior splint and observe for 6 hours
Obtain CT angiography to assess for vascular injury

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vascular surgery consultation is not indicated because this patient has an intact radial pulse and normal capillary refill, indicating preserved arterial blood flow. The clinical findings suggest radial nerve injury rather than vascular compromise.

B) INCORRECT:

Arm sling immobilization is appropriate for proximal humerus fractures, not humeral shaft fractures. In addition, the presence of radial nerve injury requires urgent orthopedic consultation rather than routine outpatient follow-up.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's clinical presentation of inability to extend the wrist (wrist drop) and decreased sensation over the dorsal first web space indicates radial nerve injury. The mechanism of injury and location of pain suggest a humeral shaft fracture, and urgent orthopedic consultation is required for potential surgical intervention. A coaptation splint is the appropriate immobilization method for humeral shaft fractures.

D) INCORRECT:

Long arm posterior splints are used for distal humerus fractures, not humeral shaft fractures. In addition, this patient's radial nerve injury requires urgent consultation, making observation inappropriate.

E) INCORRECT:

CT angiography is indicated for suspected vascular injury, but this patient has an intact vascular examination with a strong radial pulse and normal capillary refill. The clinical findings are consistent with radial nerve injury, not vascular compromise.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling onto his outstretched hand. He has severe elbow pain and refuses to move his arm. Physical examination reveals significant swelling and an S-shaped deformity of the elbow. The radial pulse is faint compared to the contralateral side, and the hand is cool to the touch. Radiographs confirm a posteriorly displaced supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Injury to which of the following arteries is the most likely cause of these vascular findings?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Supracondylar humerus fractures are the most common elbow fractures in children. In a posteriorly displaced (extension-type) fracture, the proximal fragment is displaced anteriorly, where it can impinge on, stretch, or transect the brachial artery and median nerve as they cross the antecubital fossa. Injury to the brachial artery results in vascular compromise to the forearm and hand, manifesting as a diminished or absent radial pulse, coolness, pallor, and poor capillary refill. This is a surgical emergency requiring immediate reduction to restore perfusion and prevent complications like Volkmann ischemic contracture, a permanent flexion contracture of the hand and wrist.

B) INCORRECT:

The profunda brachii (deep brachial) artery is the largest branch of the brachial artery, but it arises high in the arm and travels posteriorly with the radial nerve in the radial groove. It is primarily at risk with a mid-shaft humeral fracture. The vascular structure at risk anteriorly at the elbow joint is the main trunk of the brachial artery.

C) INCORRECT:

The ulnar artery, like the radial artery, is a terminal branch of the brachial artery that begins distal to the fracture site. Although blood flow through the ulnar artery would also be compromised by a proximal brachial artery injury, it is not the vessel directly injured by the displaced bone fragments at the supracondylar level.

D) INCORRECT:

The axillary artery is located much more proximally, within the axilla, before it becomes the brachial artery at the inferior border of the teres major muscle. An injury at the elbow, as described, would not affect the axillary artery. An axillary artery injury would be associated with a proximal humerus fracture or shoulder dislocation.

E) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is a terminal branch of the brachial artery, originating in the cubital fossa distal to the typical location of a supracondylar fracture. While the faint radial pulse is a sign of compromised blood flow through this vessel, the site of the primary arterial injury is more proximal. The injury described is at the elbow, not the forearm.
questions.hint: The major artery that runs directly anterior to the distal humerus is vulnerable to injury from the sharp, anteriorly displaced proximal fragment in this common type of elbow fracture.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department after falling from monkey bars onto his outstretched left hand. He has severe elbow pain and refuses to move his arm. On examination, there is significant swelling and an S-shaped deformity of the elbow. The radial pulse is weak compared with the contralateral side, and the hand is cool and pale. An x-ray confirms a posteriorly displaced supracondylar humerus fracture. The observed vascular compromise is most likely caused by an injury to which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The axillary artery is located much more proximally in the axilla. It becomes the brachial artery at the lower border of the teres major muscle, well superior to the elbow. An injury localized to the elbow, such as a supracondylar fracture, would not involve the axillary artery.

B) CORRECT:

The brachial artery courses anteriorly over the distal humerus before bifurcating in the cubital fossa. In a posteriorly displaced supracondylar fracture, which is the most common type, the sharp edge of the proximal humerus fragment is displaced anteriorly. This fragment can directly impinge on, stretch, entrap, or transect the brachial artery. Injury to this vessel compromises blood flow to the entire forearm and hand, leading to the classic signs of vascular insufficiency: a weak or absent radial pulse, pallor, and coolness. This is an orthopedic emergency because prolonged ischemia can lead to compartment syndrome and irreversible muscle damage, known as Volkmann ischemic contracture.

C) INCORRECT:

The median nerve runs alongside the brachial artery anterior to the elbow and is also at high risk of injury in supracondylar fractures. However, an injury to the median nerve would primarily manifest with neurologic deficits, such as sensory loss in the lateral 3.5 digits and motor weakness (e.g., inability to make an "OK" sign), rather than signs of vascular compromise such as a weak pulse, pallor, and coolness.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the radial pulse is weak, the injury is located more proximally. The radial artery is a terminal branch of the brachial artery that originates in the cubital fossa, which is typically distal to the fracture site. The diminished flow in the radial artery is a consequence of an injury to its parent vessel, not a direct injury to the radial artery at the fracture site.

E) INCORRECT:

The ulnar artery, like the radial artery, is a terminal branch of the brachial artery that arises in the cubital fossa, distal to the supracondylar region of the humerus. Therefore, it is not the structure directly injured by the displaced bone fragments in this type of fracture.
questions.hint: Consider the major neurovascular structures that run directly anterior to the distal humerus at the elbow joint, making them vulnerable to injury from a posteriorly displaced supracondylar fracture.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a direct blow to his right arm during a rugby match. He reports severe pain and swelling in his upper arm. On examination, there is a visible deformity at the mid-humerus. He is unable to extend his wrist or the metacarpophalangeal joints of his fingers. Sensation is diminished over the dorsal first web space. Distal pulses are 2+ and symmetric. Radiographs confirm a displaced, transverse fracture of the humeral shaft. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury is classically associated with fractures of the surgical neck of the humerus or anterior shoulder dislocations. This results in paralysis of the deltoid muscle, causing an inability to abduct the arm, and sensory loss over the lateral shoulder in the "sergeant's patch" area. This patient's fracture is at the mid-shaft, and his deficits involve the wrist and hand.

B) CORRECT:

The radial nerve is the most commonly injured nerve with a mid-shaft humeral fracture. It courses along the posterior aspect of the humerus in the radial (spiral) groove, making it susceptible to compression or transection. Injury to the radial nerve results in paralysis of the extensor muscles of the forearm, leading to the classic clinical sign of "wrist drop", which is the inability to extend the wrist and fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints. Sensory deficits typically occur over the dorsum of the hand, particularly in the autonomous zone of the dorsal first web space. Most of these injuries are neurapraxias and resolve with conservative management.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

Ulnar nerve injury typically occurs at the elbow (cubital tunnel) or wrist (Guyon canal). It results in weakness of the intrinsic hand muscles, causing difficulty with finger abduction and adduction, and weakness in flexing the fourth and fifth digits, leading to a "claw hand" deformity. Sensory loss affects the fifth digit and the medial half of the fourth digit.

D) INCORRECT:

Median nerve injury is more commonly associated with supracondylar humeral fractures or wrist injuries. A palsy manifests with weakness in wrist and finger flexion, forearm pronation, and thumb opposition, leading to an "ape hand" deformity. Sensory loss occurs over the palmar aspect of the first three and a half digits. This patient's deficits are in extension, not flexion.

E) INCORRECT:

An isolated injury to the musculocutaneous nerve is rare but causes weakness of the major elbow flexors (biceps brachii, brachialis) and sensory loss over the lateral forearm. This patient's primary motor deficit is an inability to extend the wrist and fingers, not flex the elbow.
questions.hint: This pathology affects a nerve that runs in the spiral groove of the humerus, making it especially vulnerable to injury from mid-shaft fractures.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She has significant pain and weakness in her right arm and hand. Physical examination shows multiple ecchymoses and tenderness in the right upper extremity. She is able to make a fist, but there is marked decrease in grip strength. An x-ray of the right upper extremity shows a midshaft humerus fracture. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

B) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with mid-shaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. It is typically associated with wrist drop, decreased finger extensor strength, and loss of sensation over the dorsal hand and forearm. Decreased grip strength can also be present due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures the optimal action of finger flexors) but the ability to make a fist is not affected.

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a mid-shaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated musculocutaneous nerve injury is rare and typically occurs as a result of trauma from chest compression or shoulder dislocation. Although such injuries can occur in motor vehicle accidents, they would manifest with impaired elbow flexion, not with decreased grip strength.
questions.hint: This patient most likely cannot extend her hand at the wrist joint.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. He has significant pain and weakness in his right arm and hand.
Physical examination reveals:

Multiple ecchymoses and tenderness on the right upper extremity

+2/4 deep tendon reflexes in the upper extremities
Ability to make a fist bilaterally
Marked decrease in grip strength in the right hand

An x-ray of the right upper extremity shows a midshaft humerus fracture. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a midshaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.

B) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a midshaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

C) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a midshaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

D) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a midshaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

E) CORRECT:

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with midshaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. This condition is typically associated with wrist drop, decreased finger extensor strength, and loss of sensation over the dorsal hand and forearm. Patients may also experience decreased grip strength due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures optimal action of finger flexors), but the ability to make a fist is not affected. Other common causes of injury to the radial nerve include direct pressure on the nerve in the axilla (e.g., due to improper use of crutches) and compression of the nerve against the humerus (e.g., Saturday night palsy).

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

F) INCORRECT:

Isolated musculocutaneous nerve injury is rare and typically occurs as a result of trauma from chest compression or shoulder dislocation. Although such injuries can occur in motor vehicle accidents, they would manifest with impaired elbow flexion, not with decreased grip strength.
questions.hint: Patients presenting with this injury would most likely also have right-sided wrist drop.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department following a motor vehicle collision. She has significant pain and weakness in her right arm and hand. Physical examination shows multiple ecchymoses and tenderness in the right upper extremity. She is able to make a fist, but there is marked decrease in grip strength. An x-ray of the right upper extremity shows a midshaft humerus fracture. Which of the following structures is most likely injured?

A) INCORRECT:

A median nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, as seen here, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control thumb opposition (thenar muscles) and flexion of the index and middle fingers (flexor digitorum superficialis, lateral belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, median nerve palsy is typically associated with supracondylar fractures rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.

Radial nerve injury is the most common complication associated with mid-shaft humerus fractures due to the radial nerve's proximity to the humerus shaft. Decreased grip strength can also be present due to impaired wrist extension (wrist extension ensures the optimal action of finger flexors) but the ability to make a fist is not affected.

See “Humerus fracture nerve palsies” table.
Image Description:

Depending on the location of humerus fractures, different anatomical structures are at risk.

Illustration indicates structures at lower risk of injury in parentheses.

C) INCORRECT:

The radial artery is unlikely to be injured by a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus because it originates below the cubital fossa as a terminal branch of the brachial artery.

D) INCORRECT:

Brachial artery injury is a possible complication of humerus fractures but is more likely to occur in a supracondylar fracture (brachial artery runs along the anteromedial aspect of the humerus) than a mid-shaft fracture. Acute limb ischemia due to brachial artery injury can cause distal weakness (e.g., decreased grip strength). However, paralysis due to acute limb ischemia is usually associated with paresthesias, which are not reported by this patient. Injury of a different structure is more likely to be the underlying cause of symptoms in this case.

E) INCORRECT:

An ulnar nerve palsy would result in decreased grip strength, but the patient would also be unable to make a fist because the muscles that control flexion of the little and ring fingers (medial belly of the flexor digitorum profundus) would also be paralyzed. In addition, ulnar nerve palsy is typically associated with fractures of the medial epicondyle of the humerus rather than a mid-shaft fracture of the humerus.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Claw hand: The 4th and 5th joints are hyperextended at the MCP and flexed at the IP joints at rest (neutral position).
- Froment sign: The patient is asked to grasp a piece of paper between the thumb and the index finger. When the examiner tries to pull the paper away, the thumb flexes at the IP joint because the flexor pollicis longus (supplied by the median nerve) compensates for the paralyzed adductor pollicis (supplied by the ulnar nerve).
Also depicted here is hollowing of the intermetacarpal spaces and the 1st web space due to the atrophy of the interossei, which is seen in chronic ulnar nerve palsy.

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: ulnar 2½ fingers (less commonly, 1½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 3rd and 4th fingers
- Palmar aspect: ulnar 1½ fingers

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory functions
Distal lesion: complete loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: This patient most likely cannot extend her hand at the wrist joint.
